did.unittitle: Alexander Graham Bell collection
did.abstract: Alexander Graham Bell (1847-1922) was born in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was granted patents in 1874 on a multiple telegraph, invented the telephone (1875) and the photophone (1880). The collection consists of works by and about Alexander Graham Bell. Includes pamphlets, reprints, proceedings, portraits and geneological information compiled by Bell and others.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alexander Graham Bell Collection (Collection 308). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Bell was born on March 3, 1847 in Edinburgh, Scotland; attended Edinburgh University; became assistant in London to his father, who originated phonetic visible speech system for teaching the deaf; his father moved the family to Canada in 1870; from 1873-77 Bell served as a professor of vocal physiology at Boston University; he was granted patents in 1874 on a multiple telegraph for sending two or more messages simultaneously over the same wire; invented telephone, 1875; in 1880 he patented the photophone; his laboratory in Braddock Bay, Nova Scotia turned out hydrofoil speedboats and aerial locomotion by way of kites; Bell served Clarke School for the Deaf at Northampton, Massachusetts for 51 years as teacher, researcher and president of the board; founding member of the National Geographic Society in 1888, and president, 1898-1903; he died in Braddock Bay, August 2, 1922.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of works by and about Alexander Graham Bell. Includes pamphlets, reprints, proceedings, portrait of Bell, Bell's letter to the Attorney General and one letter to Bell. Contains a first draft typescript of Catherine Mackenzie's book, Alexander Graham Bell (1928). Publications document Bell's experiments and interests in a variety of fields, including sheep breeding, eugenics, binaural audition, vocal physiology, aerial locomotion, and the telephone. Also includes geneological information compiled by Bell and others.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Bells of St. Andrews (genealogical).
Letters.
Catherine Mackenzie manuscript on Alexander Graham Bell.
Material regarding Bell's experiments and inventions.

did.unittitle: 1. Langdon, W.C. The Growth of the Historical Collection Reprinted from the issue of the Bell Telephone Quarterly.
2. The National Geographic Magazine. vol.14 no.6, Washington, D.C.
3. Alexander Graham Bell, Discovery And Invention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from the National Geographic Magazine, June 1914. Press of Judd & Detweiler, Incorporated. Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: 4. From the records of Alexander Graham Bell, Sex-Determination in Sheep.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from the Journal of Heredity. vol.5 no.2, Washington D.C. February 1914.

did.unittitle: 5. Alexander Graham Bell, Utility of Action And Gesture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from the Volta Review, for January 1915. Washington D.C., The Volta Bureau.

did.unittitle: 6. Photograph: Dr. Bell.
7. Alexander Graham Bell, Who Shall Inherit Long Life?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from the National Geographic Magazine. June 1919. Washington D.C. Press of Judd & Detweiler, Incorporated.

did.unittitle: 8. Alexander Graham Bell, The Mystic Oral School - An Argument in its Favor. Washington, D.C., Gibson Brothers, Printers & Bookbinders.
9. Alexander Graham Bell, A Few Thoughts Concerning Eugencies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from the National Geographic Magazine, February 1908. Washington, D.C., Press of Judd & Detweiler, Incorporated.

did.unittitle: 10. Readings in Line Writing.
11. Photograph by Bell of man looking at Sheep.
12. The National Geographic Magazine vol.19 no.1, Washington, D.C. Hubbard Memorial Hall,
13. The Bells of St. Andrews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Births, Marriages & Deaths of persons of the name of Bell; from the records of St. Andrews, Scotland. Compiled by Alexander Graham Bell.

did.unittitle: 14. Alexander Graham Bell, Experiments Relating to Binaural Audition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from the American Journal of Otology, July 1880. New York: Trow's Printing & Bookbinding Company.

did.unittitle: 15. Alexander Graham Bell, Upon the Electrical Experiments to Determine the Location of the Bullet In the Body of the Late President Garfield, And upon A Successful Form of Induction Balance for the Painless Detection of Metallic Masses in the Human Body.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With the Author's Compliments. Washington, D.C. Gibson Brothers, Printers.

did.unittitle: 16. Pound, Arthur, The Telephone Idea. New York, Greenberg, Publisher
17. Alexander Graham Bell, Prizes for the Inventor Some of the Problems Awaiting Solution.
18. Nutting, William Washburn, The 'HD-4' A 70-Miler With Remarkable Possibilities Developed At Dr. Graham Bell's laboratories on the Bras D'or Lakes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From the Smithsonian Report for 1919, Pages 205-210. (With 9 Plates) Washington Government Printing Office.

did.unittitle: 19. Sheep Catalogue of Beinn Ghreagh, Victoria County, Nova Scotia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Showing the Origin of the Multi-Nippled Sheep of Beinn Bhreagh, And Giving All the Descendants Down to 1903. Compliments of Alexander Graham Bell. Washington D.C.

did.unittitle: 20. Readings in Line Writing.
21. Bell, Alexander Melville, Visible Speech and Vocal Physiology. The Volta Bureau Washington, D.C.: Press of Gibson Brothers.
22. Proceedings of the Washington Academy of Sciences. vol.8, 9-20
23. Alexander Graham Bell, Aerial Locomotion. Published by the Academy. Washington D.C.
24. Alexander Graham Bell, Sheep-Breeding Experiments on Beinn Bhreagh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted from Science, N.S., vol.36 no.925, pp.378-384. September 20, 1912. Compliments of Alexander Graham Bell, 1331 Connecticut Ave. Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: 25. Alexander Graham Bell, The Inventor of The Electric Speaking Telephone.
26. Alexandre Graham Bell, Le Photophone De La Production Et De La Lumiere; Paris. Gauthier-Villars, Imprimeur-Libraire.
27. Letter. Alexander Graham Bell to the Attorney-General.
28. The Volta Review. Washington, D.C., vol.18 no.4,
29. Alexander Graham Bell, Acrical Locomotion with a Few Notes of Progress in the Construction of an Acrodrome.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly President of the National Geographic Society (Dr. Bell). Reprinted from the National Geographic Magazine, January 1907. Press of Judd & Detweiler, Incorporated.

did.unittitle: 30. Bell, A. Melville, Pronunzia Inglese Visible. Insegnata. In Dodici Lezioni Catalogue of Works.
31. Photo duplicated manuscripts relating to Bell's parents. Written for the Beinn Bhreagh Recorder
32. Mounted photograph of Alexander Graham Bell.
33. Portrait of Dr. Bell receiving an academic degree; Edinburgh.
34. Alexander Graham Bell, by Catherine Mackenzie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: First draft, to be edited and revised. Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1928.

did.unittitle: 35. Letter to Alexander Graham Bell from John Macleov, encloses death certificate and receipt in the sum of $10.00.
